lom:description.lom:string:
NSF report is divided into: Sky, Sea, Ice, Land, Life and People.
Excerpt: "Our planet's climate affects--and is affected by--the sky, land, ice, sea, life, and people found on it. To understand the entire story of climate change we must study all of the natural and human systems that contribute to and interact with Earth's climate system.
Innovative scientists and engineers have responded to the call for alternative energy sources that reduce the amount of carbon dioxide we put into the atmosphere. Computer scientists are creating new tools for geoscientists, decision-makers and the public to understand Earth's changing climate. Social scientists are studying human decisions and behaviors that influence the environment. By studying such issues as the energy grid, land use, urban planning, building materials and economic factors that are linked to anthropogenic climate change, researchers are beginning to tackle some of the more nuanced, but essential, questions regarding the human impact on, and response to, the Earth's changing climate."
Image caption: eologist Tracy Jones gives high school students a hands-on opportunity to learn about their local marine environment. NSF's Centers for Ocean Science Education Excellence integrates ocean science research into high-quality education programs, promoting a deeper public understanding of the oceans and their influence on our quality of life and national prosperity.

lom:keyword.lom:string: Climate change, global warming, greenhouse gases
